awd_abstract_narration: As our e-mail, medical, financial and other personal information is migrating to the Web, the need to simultaneously guarantee privacy, availability of data, and correctness of computations is a paramount concern for NSF and for our society. This workshop will explore mathematical tools for addressing these needs. The workshop will also address the ongoing concerted effort to create practical solutions and new technologies based on these mathematical developments.  The workshop will be open to all potential participants, and the findings (including videos of presentations) will be distributed to the public for comments and engagement. This award will support students to attend the workshop, and the PI will actively recruit scientists from a diversity of backgrounds. The mathematical tools that will be considered include integer lattices, elliptic curves, bi-linear and multi-linear maps, codes, and computational learning theory.

The second workshop of the program on Cryptography, entitled “The Mathematics of Modern Cryptography,” took place the week of July 6-10, 2015. The workshop was devoted to the investigation of a number of emerging problems in cryptographic research, where mathematics plays a fundamental role. The workshop took place over the course of five days, each dedicated to a specific theme as follows:

  1. Monday: Advanced applications of lattice-based cryptography
  2. Tuesday: Efficient cryptography based on lattices from algebraic number theory, and algorithmic/cryptanalytic attacks
  3. Wednesday: Arithmetic cryptography and randomized encodings
  4. Thursday: Interactive coding and non-malleable codes
  5. Friday: Multilinear maps and non-commutative cryptography

In addition, on Monday afternoon, the workshop hosted a seminar from the “Historical Papers” series, organized by Daniel Wichs and Vinod Vaikuntanathan for the duration of the whole Cryptography program. Closely matching the theme of the workshop, the historical talk for this week was delivered by Daniele Micciancio (one of the workshop organizers) on the  history of lattice based cryptography. Wednesday afternoon was left open to give all invited participants a chance to talk about their latest research and speculative ideas, and to allow student presentations on recent work.

Each day started with one or two semi-tutorial “anchor” talks, each at least one hour in length, aimed at bringing the whole audience up to speed with the problems and techniques related to the theme of the day. A small number of shorter and more technical talks followed in the afternoon, still leaving ample opportunities for the workshop participants to interact and discuss problems in one-on-one or small group meetings.

On Monday, Daniel Wichs, Zvika Brakerski, Vinod Vaikuntanathan and Hoeteck Wee gave a set of coordinated talks on advanced cryptographic primitives based on lattice problems: fully homomorphic encryption, fully homomorphic signatures, attribute-based encryption and predicate encryption. These are all advanced cryptographic functions that allow one to perform computations on encrypted (or digitally signed) data, a topic that is receiving much attention because of its potential applicability to cloud computing.

On Tuesday the focus shifted from the construction of lattice-based cryptographic functions to their security evaluation. After a tutorial presentation on “ring-lattices” by Damien Stehle, the day featured a series of technical talks on the latest algorithmic developments that can be used to attack lattice cryptographic functions. Noah Stephens-Davidowitz presented the (recently discovered) fastest known algorithm to find exact solutions to the main computational problems used in lattice cryptography. Ludovic Perret presented a new class of algebraic attacks, based on Groebner basis computation. Kristin Lauter followed with an analysis of certain ring lattices for which lattice cryptography can be easily broken, and Nadia Heninger closed the day with a presentation on how even good cryptographic functions can fail in practice due to weaknesses in popular internet protocols.

Wednesday and Thursday mornings were dedicated to a different area of mathematics that often arises in the study of cryptography: coding theory.
